title:
Analysis and Visualisation of Musical Audio and Video Movement
    Synchrony Data
text: goal movementsync library provide analysis visualisation synchrony, interaction, joint movements audio video movement data group music performers. Functions library offer analysis routines visualising, selecting, filtering data. Analysis functions carrying Granger causality analysis wavelet analysis included. Routines combining movement data, music instrument onsets, annotations also offered library. documentation, see Quick Guide. Note: Movement data obtained analysis videos using suitable computer vision techniques (e.g. openpose obtaining motion capture data. Similarly, onset data extracted audio recordings using onset detection algorithms. Also, annotations rhythmic structures, musical events, musical form ensemble performances can carried ELAN another annotation tool audio video. movementsync library deal initial extraction pose video onsets audio, offers versatile suite functions analyse extracted data. library supports open data described Clayton, Leante, Tarsitani (2021) doi:10.17605/OSF.IO/KS325. Example analyses can found Clayton, Jakubowski, Eerola (2019) doi:10.1177/1029864919844809. Wavelet analysis techniques applied musical interactions reported Eerola et al. (2018) doi:10.1098/rsos.171520.

text: load short demo data comes package. data 1 min video/feature data (1500 observations 25 frames per second (fps) taken North Indian Raga performance Anupama Bhagwat (sitar) Gurdain Rayatt (Tabla) performing Rag Puriya (Recording ID NIR_ABh_Puriya available OSF. first video frame performance shown image . can use external datasets longer demonstrations extensive examples. frame video pose estimation done Get markers sitar player plot .  Plot Y coordinate nose marker sitar player.
code: library(movementsync) r1 <- get_sample_recording()                                                # Defaults to NIR_ABh_Puriya rv1 <- get_raw_view(r1, "Central", "", "Sitar")                             # Take the sitar player pv1 <- get_processed_view(rv1) dp <- c("LWrist","RWrist","LElbow","RElbow","LEye","REye","Neck","MidHip")  # Define markers fv1 <- apply_filter_sgolay(pv1, data_point = dp, n = 41, p = 4)             # Apply smoothing distribution_dp(fv1)                                                        # Plot autoplot(pv1, columns = c("Nose_y"))                        # Define markers/coords and plot

text: Next split data 30-second segments 6-second step size create segments tested Granger causality analysis. extremely blunt way performing analysis illustrates procedure.  Now apply Granger analysis segments test musicians influence segment. null hypothesis Tabla doesn’t influence Sitar p-values analysis plotted indicator strength causality.  can see visualisation, much causality taking place two performers evidenced high p values. last segments suggest weak causality sitar can seen driving tabla. interpretation 30-second segments vertical head movement challenging, especially know sitar player musician producing sounds first 60-seconds opening alap. tabla player may still reacting performance sitar player coordinating actions performance cues (gaze) opening section.
code: splicing_df <- splice_time(jv, win_size = 30, step_size = 6)            # Splice into segments sv <- get_spliced_view(jv, splicing_df)                                 # Prepare the data        autoplot(sv,columns = c('Nose_y_Central_Sitar','Nose_y_Central_Tabla')) # Plot selected coordinates g <- granger_test(sv,                    "Nose_y_Central_Sitar", "Nose_y_Central_Tabla",                    lag = 12/25)                                 # apply granger analysis autoplot(g, splicing_df = splicing_df)                         # show p-values (forward and backwards)

title: Test for Conditional Granger Causality — ms_condgrangertest
Test for Conditional Granger Causality — ms_condgrangertest
code: data(wages, package = "lmtest") diff_wages <- diff(wages)  # Granger tests lmtest::grangertest(diff_wages[, 'w'], diff_wages[, 'CPI'], order = 3) #> Granger causality test #>  #> Model 1: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "w"], 1:3) #> Model 2: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) #>   Res.Df Df      F  Pr(>F)   #> 1      7                     #> 2     10 -3 7.5653 0.01338 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 ms_grangertest1(diff_wages[, 'w'], diff_wages[, 'CPI'], order = 3) #> Granger causality test #>  #> Model 1: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "w"], 1:3) #> Model 2: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) #>   Res.Df Df      F  Pr(>F)   #> 1      7                     #> 2     10 -3 7.5653 0.01338 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 ms_grangertest2(diff_wages[, 'w'], diff_wages[, 'CPI'], order = 3) #> Granger causality test #>  #> Model 1: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "w"], 1:3) #> Model 2: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) #>   Res.Df Df      F  Pr(>F)   #> 1      7                     #> 2     10 -3 7.5653 0.01338 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1  ms_condgrangertest(diff_wages[, 'w'], diff_wages[, 'CPI'], diff_wages[, 'u'], order = 3) #> Conditional Granger causality test #> Model 1: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "w"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "u"], 1:3) #> Model 2: diff_wages[, "CPI"] ~ Lags(diff_wages[, "CPI"], 1:3) + Lags(diff_wages[, "u"], 1:3) #>  #>   Res.Df Df      F  Pr(>F)   #> 1      4                     #> 2      7 -3 5.7136 0.06273 . #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

title: movementsync 0.1.4
